fields.physical_description:
Hanging for a mosque or shrine. Resist dyed, block printed, painted, pain weave cotton, probably hand woven.
There is an undecorated red border around four sides and then [1] a border with a white and yellow ground [it varies] and a line of lozenges framed with blue leaves enclosing simple red rosettes.
Described from the top downwards: there is a wide band with a white ground and a blue leafy meander bearing large red, black and light blue and yellow exotic blossoms and buds.
[2] a narrow composite band with a white ground and a single line of white and blue botehs separated by flower heads in four variations.
[3] a band with a series of horizontal undulating stripes forming an ogival pattern in red, yellow, blue, white and red with a yellow and then blue centre; all decorated with either a delicate floral meander or floral sprigs.
[4] a narrow band of alternate blue, white and yellow lozenges with red floral elements.
Then there is a deep section [34 cm deep] with a cusped arch with yellow spandrels decorated with a green stemmed spray with blue, white and red blossoms and buds.  The apex of the arch is marked by two large tulip-like heads in similar colours.  In the arch, on a cream ground, is a painted inscription and block-printed cartouche with a smaller inscription.
Bands [4], [3] and [1] are repeated.
There is a less deep section with a red ground and a cream cartouche and painted inscription.
This arrangement of bands [4], [3] and [1] and a section with an inscription is repeated, giving seven in total, followed by a repetition of bands [4], [3] and [1].
At the bottom there is [5] a band with a repeating pattern of arches in blue with red spandrels and isolated flower heads in 8 variations followed by a repetition of band [2], a mirror image of band [5] and finally a repetition of band [1].
Canvas patches have been attached to the upper corners at the back to strengthen them for hanging; there is one loop at the right hand corner.
fields.dimensions: Length: 278.5 cm, Width: 45 cm selvedge to selvedge
fields.materials_techniques: cotton yarn, weaving, resist dyeing, block printing, painting.
fields.marks:
O Aba Abdullah al-Hussain-i shahid
Printed textile
Haji Aqa Muhammad Husain Ahmad
One hundred threads [of the highest quality]
Incomplete verses written by the poet Mulana Muhtashim-i Kashani from the Safavid period:
What is this popular upheaval in the world again?
What is this sadness and mourning again?
what is this great apocalypse that without the sounding of the trumpet of [the angel] Esrafil has risen fro mthe earth to high heaven again?
I would not be far from the truth if I call this the world's day of ressurection; this all-encompassing apocalypse that is called Moharram.
It is as if the sun rises from the west.
fields.history_note:
Originally described as an 18th century hanging. 
Given by Sir Charles Marling, British Legation, Tehran
The RD includes a partial translation of the inscription
